I'll be honest here, it's gone. Even in the scenario that it was A) only deleted but not overwritten or B) whole disk shallowly/quickly formatted and unused after that, only then you'd have a chance to recover something going from nothing to maybe part of the tree directory but you did overwrite with old files, probably the newly written stuff wasn't actually written over the old stuff on the disk, but the metadata needed to follow the tree directory may be lost and blah blah... gg newest KxoIDs
Qt!

I personally try to think that all knowledge should be preserved and accessible. I'd probably disregard the nature of it and seed it unless seeding it could incur in a risk (stuff that could get me jailed, killed for sure). I dislike banning as it fully blocks all the new stuff other users post and I could be missing a lot of gold in that sea of trash.
It's not the latest...

Thanks for the heads-up, I quickly adopted the use of name.YO plugin for DNS, the zite is also accessible with it's default address of [/1D6QfsBSZHmYWbuCxKG5ya31BiTczoZiES](/1D6QfsBSZHmYWbuCxKG5ya31BiTczoZiES). I'll remove the usage of the name.yo plugin until I can make it work seamlessly for clients with and without the plugin. There was a talk about that for the plugin.

Updated the zite, not it's up to date with the original clearnet and it's not sporting a domain address (although, it is still reachable through rexresearch.zn). Hope this fixes the issue until zerohello is updated to be aware of name.yo domain names. 
PS: Thanks for seeding the zite so much, I try to keep a node always up for it but downtime isn't non-existent.

@Draugrdeathlord: Thank you beforehand then. Mind that the zite has some files that are over the default 10MB for auto downloading optional files, so if you are trying to seed it fully you'll need to raise that to something bigger; the bigger file as of now is [rodin/v1-LEDcoilmotor.mp4](/1D6QfsBSZHmYWbuCxKG5ya31BiTczoZiES/rodin/v1-LEDcoilmotor.mp4), weighing around 103MB.

Arch is top shit as long as you don't assume upgrades will go smoothly, installers are nice and all but you don't learn much with them, also, archlinux's wiki is so god damn great that many distros and users of other distros would point to it for reference, so it encourages reading it (and manuals). After all, arch linux (among others like gentoo, slackware and suicide linux...) aren't meant for newcomers nor butter-smooth out-of-box user experience.
